intro: Pimpinella rupestris, commonly known as the rock parsley, is a flowering plant native to rocky and arid regions of the Mediterranean. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its finely divided leaves and small, white or yellowish flowers. The plant typically grows in crevices and on rocky outcrops, showcasing its adaptability to harsh environments. Its seeds are small and dry, often dispersed by wind, and it is valued for its ornamental appeal and ecological role in stabilizing soil in rocky areas.
